Writing novels is a challenge, while writing short stories is a joy. It is like planting a forest or a garden. The two processes complement each other, creating a complete landscape. Writing novels is like planting a forest, and writing short stories is like planting a garden. The two processes take different parts of the brain and require different time commitment.

Since the beginning of my career, I have alternated between writing novels and short stories. I write novels and short stories in different sequences. I never write short stories while I’m writing a novel, and I never write a novel while I’m working on short stories.

Writing short stories is a necessary change of pace and offers several benefits. It takes less time to finish, and you can create a story out of the smallest things. You don’t have to worry about failing, and you can learn from your mistakes and use that in the next story you write.

My short stories are like soft shadows I have set out in the world, faint footprints I have left behind. They are like guideposts to my heart, and it makes me happy as a writer to be able to share these intimate feelings with my readers.<eos>

From around 2015, major publishers started to report that sales of ebooks had plateaued or even fallen in some cases. This has raised concerns about the long-term potential of ebooks in the publishing industry. Some people believe that the ebooks hype may have driven unwise investment, with companies losing confidence in the power of the word on the page. Despite the evidence suggesting that digital and print can coexist in the market, the question of whether the ebook will ‘kill’ the print book still continues to surface.

The idea of one medium ‘killing’ another has often followed the unveiling of new technologies. Even before the advent of digital technologies, critics have predicted the demise of existing media. For example, when television was invented, many people claimed that radio would die. But radio ended up surviving by finding new uses. The same has happened with other technologies, such as movies, radio, and the phonograph.

The spread of the printing press in 15th-century Europe, the shift from silent to sound movie in the 1920s, and the shift from analog to digital photography are all examples of how new technologies have impacted our relationship with books. Not surprisingly, e-readers have stimulated a new appreciation for the material quality of ‘old’ books.

This should provide some reassurance to those who still worry about the disappearance of print books. However, the idea of the disappearing medium will continue to provide an appealing narrative about both the transformative power of technology and our aversion to change.<eos>

In a zoo in Sweden, a chimpanzee named Santino would sometimes break up concrete into pieces and throw them at visitors. Was he being spiteful? In caves in the US, female bats help unrelated fruit bat mothers if they can’t find the right birthing position. Are they being caring? Fifty years ago, people thought that animals didn’t have consciousness, feelings or moral systems. But recently that has partially changed. Thanks to research into the behaviour of bats, chimps, not to mention rats, dolphins and chickens, emotions of animals have gone from being a taboo area of investigation to being tentatively explored. The new research has started a debate about whether animals can be said to have consciousness. This debate stimulates a second, much less abstract, one: not of consciousness, but conscience – a person’s moral sense of right and wrong that guides their behaviour. If, as this research seems to imply, cows enjoy problem-solving, what does it mean for the production and consumption of beef? The observations may not be disputed, but the interpretation of them is. There are different views on what the new research means for the production and consumption of beef. Some people believe that we should stop eating meat altogether, while others believe that we should at the very least re-evaluate our view of animal cognition. The debate about animal consciousness is a complex one and there is no easy answer.<eos>

It involves analyzing, evaluating, and judging information based on its relevance, accuracy, and credibility. Technology can complement and enhance human thinking, but it can also make it more difficult to think critically.

There are concerns that the increasing presence of technology is changing the way we approach complex problems and making it more difficult to really think. For example, the overuse of visual media and the decline in reading have contributed to a decline in critical thinking skills. However, there is also evidence that technology can improve some types of information processing and decision-making.

It is important to understand the subtleties of how technology affects thinking and analysis in order to make the most of our capabilities. By taking a closer look at technology and understanding its impact on our cognitive abilities, we can develop strategies to enhance our critical thinking skills and make better decisions.<eos>

The silence on Centre Court at the Wimbledon tennis championships is very calming. You can bounce the ball, serve, and hit it, and hear the echo of your own shot. The trimmed grass, the rich history, the ancient stadium, the players dressed in white, and the respectful crowds all combine to create a feeling of enclosure and comfort. The quiet of the Centre Court is good for my game. It helps me to focus on the point I’m playing and to shut everything else out.

The silence is broken by a sudden noise when a point is done: applause, cheers, and people shouting your name. You hear them, but as if from a distant place. You don’t register that there are thousands of people watching you. You are so focused that you have no sense at all that there are millions watching you as you play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final.

I had always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. I had played and lost against Federer in the final the year before, and the year before that. The defeat in 2006 had not been so hard. I went out onto the court that time just pleased and grateful that I had made it that far. But my defeat in 2007 left me utterly destroyed. I knew I could have done better, that it was not my ability or the quality of my game that had failed me, but my head. I wept after that loss.
